column5: I‚Äôd leave the same note for now and see if you can apply for a parking permit that you can use for the next 12 months
Mine went v well so I wouldn‚Äôt hesitate to use them outside of monsoon season :)

Sorry I hadn‚Äôt logged in for a while! The flights with air swift went well :) one left one time, the other was an hour late (but I think the delay was Manila‚Äôs fault, that airport is awful!). Aircraft clean and new, I‚Äôd definitely use them again

This is where I stayed! Honestly it‚Äôs incredible. The accommodation, the local guides who take you exploring, even the food was delicious! Three nights was just right in my opinion, we had time to do all the things we wanted to do, as you get your own private guide and boat driver, so you can see loads even in one day. The amount of wildlife there is amazing.

My favourite thing was being out on the river for sunrise and sunset. Nothing prepared me for how stunning that was. Totally recommend getting up early to do the sunrise bird watching, we even saw pink dolphins :)

I‚Äôve seen SO many people like this on flights. Extremely rude imo. Have some common sense and please don‚Äôt make us get the air stewards involved. 

On some flights they go around and check before they serve the food - that‚Äôs the best!

Wow so rude! I‚Äôve had people put their hair over the back of the chair, also blocking my screen. Why do people think that‚Äôs ok? Luckily my person moved it when I said but they definitely thought I was the odd one

So true, it really is all relative. I work in London and live in a rip-off commuter town so wouldn‚Äôt even need to move abroad to feel rich, I could just move 50 miles up North and buy a mansion for half the price of my tiny house. Problem is there‚Äôs no jobs... 

Very envious of your Mexican hotel lifestyle. I would love to make a move like this one day

I‚Äôm not going to argue too much with the stats, other than to say that it‚Äôs a pretty small sample size (just 200 people to represent a whole country) and it‚Äôs opt in, so it‚Äôs hard to say it‚Äôs not biased. Those opposing the government are less likely submit their views. 

However your last paragraph is sadly untrue. The Burmese people have never been able to stand up to the government, and their support has rarely mattered. The country was closed off for many years, and there‚Äôs a whole generation of people who didn‚Äôt get a proper education as a result. 

From the [BBC](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12990563) : ‚Äú1990 - Opposition National League for Democracy (NLD) wins landslide victory in elections, but the military ignores the result.‚Äù This went on until 2011. 

Not saying you‚Äôre wrong with this, and not justifying what‚Äôs going on in any way shape or form,  I‚Äôm just saying it‚Äôs far more complicated than what the people want.

Very sweet of you, I‚Äôm sure she is grateful :). My mum is honestly the last person that needs a fancy holiday buying for her... but my in-laws would very much appreciate it as they have only ever been to Spain (from the UK) on the cheap. The spending money is actually for them. But a full holiday may have to wait!

A Mercedes-Benz?? Insane.
Right? I thought ¬£100 spending money was generous. Time to re-evaluate my Christmas gifts...

I felt the same way but took the plunge and I‚Äôm glad I did. It‚Äôs one of the countries I have enjoyed the most in SE Asia (there‚Äôs just so much to see and it‚Äôs so quiet!) and everyone we met was so incredibly kind. It‚Äôs a tough time to be a local there right now, and these people who are trying to just get by are not the people committing atrocities. They were very open on their political views and the people I met do not support what‚Äôs happening in the north. 

Ultimately it‚Äôs up to you, and how you feel, but I was glad I visited and heard what the people had to say.
This is what I would do. Make a cute certificate then plan it together (maybe give a budget to set expectations!)

I would advise against Langkawi as agree it doesn‚Äôt fit your brief. 

In my opinion, the main Bali beaches are overcrowded and dirty, I didn‚Äôt enjoy seminyak. There was no beach bungalow vibe here that I saw. 

How about Gili Trawangan? It‚Äôs a short ferry from either Bali or Lombok. I stayed in a beach bungalow for a great price on the quieter (north) side of the island and it was incredibly peaceful and relaxing. The place was Desa Dunia Beda and could be worth checking out :)

This is all great advice. My last company made someone wait 2 hours for an interview once and I was horrified. It was an awful place to work generally. A disorganised interview process is such a giveaway. 

I currently work in a small company and it definitely involves wearing every damn hat. For me that‚Äôs enjoyable (mostly) but I totally get why others would hate it
I love this story so much! Power to the people!

How about Hanoi and Hoi An? For Hoi An you can stay on the beach rather than in the old town if you prefer, then it‚Äôs just a ten minute shuttle bus (usually free) to a UNESCO heritage site but you also have the beach. 

I loved both Hoi An and Hanoi and would recommend this over HCMC

I mean I didn‚Äôt find it as bad as you have described but also I didn‚Äôt love NY. It was ok for a day but it‚Äôs really not the most exciting city I‚Äôve visited. We did all the big sights and ate a ton of food (this bit was definitely a highlight!) but I wouldn‚Äôt be bothered to never return. Everyone is different though, I know many that love it!

I don‚Äôt know... I work in an office in London and there‚Äôs a fair bit of joking about the ‚ÄúNorth‚Äù. Especially when our poor Liverpool colleague is down.

Yeah it‚Äôs the darkness. Honestly it‚Äôs so depressing to have it go dark at 4pm, and still have 2 hours of work to go. And even when the sun is up, the sky is often grey. Dark and dank pretty much sums it up. 

I was in Calgary last month and even though it was colder, the weather was so much less depressive!

I would do Japan but that‚Äôs just because I find Asia way more exciting than Europe (as it‚Äôs easy access for me). 

I definitely wouldn‚Äôt skip Tokyo though. Everyone I know preferred it to Kyoto - which can be super touristy and busy (think crowds of people waving selfie sticks). Tokyo is awesome and there is so much to explore. I may divide the crowd with this one, but it definitely felt more authentic.

The food was also way better (and better value) in Tokyo - since you said food was a key interest! I‚Äôd go back there just to eat
Cute! Looks like my boy did when he was a kitten :)
Oh man. I went on a boat deep into the Amazon on my honeymoon. So glad I didn‚Äôt read this before we went!
So cute! I have a ginger & white and a calico cat too :)

Completely agree! How can it not be the real Japan when it‚Äôs the capital city? I felt much closer to local life in Tokyo than I did in Kyoto, which was far more plagued with tourists and selfie sticks!
Yes immediately thought of Croatia! Incredibly blue and clear waters
What do you like about London? I‚Äôm there 4 days a week so genuinely interested!
I‚Äôd love to go back to Tokyo! So many people seem to hate on it but I found it to be an incredible place to visit

When I went to Thailand I got all my jabs for free on the NHS. The Fit for Travel website is useful for seeing what you need. Definitely don‚Äôt go to a private clinic - they charge a fortune for the same jabs

I‚Äôd you‚Äôre going in November then best to avoid Koh Samui and nearby islands. It can be very wet there this time of year. Anywhere near Phuket is much safer. 

I went to Koh Samui in Jan and we experienced a terrible storm. Locals said that dry season there didn‚Äôt start until February. One told us that sometimes it rained a week straight in November. So really spends on which Thai islands.

I agree with everyone else - partners should be invited. I had a couple of people I‚Äôd never met at my wedding (of circa 65 people) and I actually thought it was quite nice! These people came all the way to celebrate our day, and some hadn‚Äôt met either of us yet. We had fun with all of them :)

Keep your guests happy and everyone will have a better day!

How about Phu Quoc? It‚Äôs a direct flight from Hanoi.

Edit - sorry realise you said different country! I‚Äôm not sure there are any direct flight to beaches from Hanoi (but others may correct me). However with one week, you‚Äôd have time to fly direct to Siem Reap, visit Angkor Wat and spend a few nights on Koh Rong. That would be my top choice I think.
Wow this is so nice and genuinely made me tear up! As someone whose lost someone close, this sort of thing means the world
So cute

Wow yeah I remember the locals saying at the time (almost 3 years ago now) that there wasn‚Äôt enough being done to protect it. It‚Äôs so sad as I really did think it was a truly beautiful place. When we were out away from the docks I could only ever see one other boat by ours, so it felt peaceful. All I‚Äôve heard is bad things ever since though :(

Ps. Shit show is one of my favourite phrases
Fair point and think you‚Äôre totally right. I also thought OP was right to shine a light on this area. It‚Äôs can‚Äôt be a one size fits all solution for everyone - nor the only option!

I found Peru very clean and hygienic compared to places like SE Asia. I didn‚Äôt feel at all worried about getting sick from food. And I‚Äôm usually pretty paranoid. 

I‚Äôd just follow usual precautions like only drinking bottled water and avoiding people who are visibly sick (coughing, holding their head with their hands). 

Our summertime there is flu season and my husband caught a nasty bug off a local kid who was coughing and spluttering over everyone on an internal flight.

I agree. I did one night and it was great! Didn‚Äôt see any garbage though.. found it pretty peaceful once you got away from the dock and other boats. This was 2016 though so maybe it‚Äôs become busier?

If it‚Äôs February I‚Äôd pick Thailand, Vietnam or Malaysia. It‚Äôs not meant to be the best time of year for Indonesia (June to Sept is your best bet for dry season). 

I‚Äôve done all of them and love them equally. I‚Äôd have a look at which excites you more. For me, Thailand had the most impressive temples, Vietnam had incredibly varied scenery and Malaysia had the most exciting food. But it really depends where you go within each. If you plan the trip well you can‚Äôt go wrong with any of them

For two weeks on honeymoon, I‚Äôd do something like this:

Thailand
- Bangkok - Khao Sok - Krabi/Koh Lanta or equivalent beach stop

Vietnam 
- Hanoi - Sapa or Halong Bay - Hoi An - Phu Quoc

Malaysia 
- Kuala Lumpur - Cameron Highlands - Penang - Langkawi
Yes! I loved Mexico City but rarely see it mentioned. None of my UK friends have been

I got a stinking cold before my first city break with my (now) husband. We still had a great time. Like everyone else says, stock up on all the medicine you want (I highly recommend throat lozenges with a light anaesthetic for the plane and at night, if you get a tickly throat. The dry air is a killer. I‚Äôd also bring Lemsip to have as a pick me up at breakfast). 

Have a great trip :)

Just call up each airline. Be extra polite and see if they can help you without a charge. I pulled this off once with EasyJet who are notoriously tight with this stuff, and state fees for name changes online. Good luck!

I think we were in the bus queue to go up at about 7.30am, got through the gates around 8, and were back down by 11. We got straight on the bus after exiting as the queues down are really short at this time. We went two days in a row so we did the main loop on day 1 (with a guide) and then just took more photos and did one of the gentler walks on day 2. Definitely could be done in one trip though. 

The maximum time inside is 4 hours (although I can‚Äôt see how it‚Äôs regulated). There‚Äôs no toilets or water for sale inside the site, so this does limit how long you can stay. Definitely take plenty of water with you!

Either way, 4pm train is more than late enough including time for a long lunch, browsing shops, and a coffee stop. 

Hope this helps :)

Happy to help with Oxford. Best journey from London is to get the train from Paddington which takes 1 hour. Make sure you travel off peak to avoid extra high fares. 

Once at Oxford station (do not go to Oxford Parkway, it‚Äôs outside the city), you can walk into the centre. 

If it was me, I would:
- admire the Bridge of Sighs and the Radcliffe Camera
- climb St Mary‚Äôs church tower
- get coffee at a cute independent like The Missing Bean. Great coffee and food too
- visit the covered market and see the oldest ham in the world. Also lots of food options 
- visit a museum (Natural History, Pitt Rivera, Ashmolean)
-  take in a university college. There are so many to pick from!
- end the day at a local pub like The Turf - which is fun as it‚Äôs hidden down a secret alley. Or The White Rabbit which does amazing pizza too

All of this can be done on foot. No need for any transport. 

Hope this helps :)

Chief Exec in the U.K. and get 25 days off + bank holidays and we also have Christmas shutdown. I only take time off if I‚Äôm leaving the country, and I book my time around weekends and bank holidays to maximise travel time. I‚Äôve never had a career break to go travelling or even gap year, so this is my compromise

I‚Äôve been to all three and loved all of the resorts we picked. They were Secrets Akumal in Mexico, Dreams La Romana (now Hilton La Romana) in Dom Rep, and Royalton Hicacos in Varadero, Cuba. All are adults only. 

I actually really enjoyed doing 3 night Havana and 4 nights Varadero if you end up picking Cuba.

I interpreted it as a friend with iPhone versus a professional photographer. Not only do you get someone who knows how to use a camera properly, but also someone who will instruct on the best poses - and be there to line up the shot just right. I have zero regrets on paying for my photographer for this reason :)
I would definitely add on another stop. So many options from Singapore! I‚Äôd pick which ever interests you the most. You could even go to an island destination if you didn‚Äôt want to do 2 cities.

Yes this is a great tip! I often do circles online, with 20 tabs open, not documenting anything and then losing motivation. The pursuit of perfection is a blessing and a curse sometimes. Luckily once I get through the information overload stage, I‚Äôm pretty happy with my trip plan

Trainline is the most user friendly but you do have to pay a small booking fee versus using National Rail which is the official app. 

For getting around on the underground or buses in London, you want Citymapper.

For getting around on local buses elsewhere I just use Google Maps. It has live times too.

It‚Äôs a tricky one. For me and my husband, we have mostly agreed to do things our own way. I can‚Äôt watch him wash up though as I hate how much water he wastes!

Yeah I accidentally turned my dryer on with my cat in. I‚Äôd left some towels in there but had got distracted before putting it on, and came back and just turned it in without checking - as I had no idea he‚Äôd ever paid any interest in the dryer. Thankfully I heard a weird thump so stopped it instantly. Opened the door was there was my poor boy, a bit shaken up. Still terrifies me to this day!

This is pretty intense. Does he insist that you wear a shower cap to cook too? I would 100% have to draw the line at that. 

But I certainly have some of my own ‚Äúrules‚Äù on how things should be done. Going to do some reflecting on how reasonable/unreasonable they are as a result of this thread!

I went through this exact thing a few years back and yeah, it feels awkward, but you‚Äôve got to go with your gut. I actually ended up leaving, despite feeling unsure, and despite a great counter offer from a senior director, and I did regret it. 

Can you speak to your manager and let her know the situation? That might slow down her interview process then if she wants to keep you
